symptom: About womb cancer
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Causes of womb cancer
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Radiotherapy, chemotherapy or hormone therapy can reduce symptoms such as pain by shrinking the cancer or slowing its growth.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: pain in the back, legs, or pelvis
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: It’s mainly used to treat advanced-stage womb cancers, or cancer that has come back, and can help shrink the tumour and control any symptoms.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: In 2015, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) published guidelines to help GPs recognise the signs and symptoms of gynaecological cancer and refer people for the right tests faster. To find out if you should be referred for further tests for suspected endometrial cancer, read the NICE 2015 guidelines on Suspected Cancer: Recognition and Referral.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Your GP will probably carry out a physical examination of your pelvic area, including your vagina, womb, ovaries, and bladder. They will ask about your symptoms, when they happen, and how often.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: a computerised tomography (CT) scan – where a series of X-rays are used to create a detailed image of the inside of your body to check if the cancer has spread
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Your GP will examine you and ask about your symptoms. They will refer you to a specialist for further tests if they suspect you may have a serious problem, or if they are unsure about a diagnosis.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: If you’re told nothing more can be done to treat your womb cancer, your care will focus on controlling your symptoms and helping you to be as comfortable as possible. This is called palliative care. Palliative care also includes psychological, social and spiritual support for you and your family or carers.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Less common symptoms include pain in the lower abdomen (tummy) and pain during sex.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Diagnosing womb cancer
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Cancer of the womb (uterus) is a common cancer that affects the female reproductive system. It’s also called uterine cancer and endometrial cancer.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Read more about the causes of womb cancer
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Diabetes causes an increase in the amount of insulin in your body, which in turn can raise your oestrogen levels.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: vomiting
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: If you have stage 3 or 4 womb cancer, you may be given a course of chemotherapy. Chemotherapy can be used after surgery to try to prevent the return of the cancer. In cases of advanced cancer, it may be used to slow the spread of the cancer and relieve symptoms.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: Even if your cancer is advanced and the chances of a cure are small, treatment can still help to relieve symptoms and prolong your life.
name: Womb (uterus) cancer

symptom: If you haven’t already had the menopause, removing the ovaries means you’ll go through an early menopause. Symptoms can include vaginal dryness and loss of sexual desire.

symptom: If after surgery the chance of the cancer coming back is very low, your doctor might suggest you have surveillance. This means having regular checks to look for signs of the cancer coming back. If it does come back and it’s picked up very early, then it’s easy to cure. If the cancer doesn’t come back then you’ve avoided having unnecessary treatment. At each clinic appointment, your doctor will examine you and you may have blood tests and chest X-rays.

symptom: Treatment for varicose eczema aims to improve the condition of your skin, treat your symptoms and help improve your circulation (blood flow).
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: There are some steps you can take to reduce the symptoms of varicose eczema and help prevent further problems, such as:
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: try to avoid injuring your skin – injuries to your skin could lead to an ulcer developing
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: ligation and stripping – where affected veins are tied off and surgically removed
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: scaly or crusty
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: If you have varicose eczema, you should use an emollient at least twice a day, even if you do not have any symptoms.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: itchy
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: raise your legs when you are resting – for example, by propping up your feet on some pillows (ideally so that they are above the level of your heart), as this can help reduce swelling
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: If these treatments don’t help, your GP may refer you to a dermatologist (skin specialist) in case there is another cause for your symptoms or if they are concerned you may also have a type of eczema called contact dermatitis.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: See your GP if you have symptoms of varicose eczema. They can usually make a diagnosis by simply looking at the affected areas.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: red, tender and tight skin that can eventually become hardened (lipodermatosclerosis)
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: brown discolouration of the skin
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: pain
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: eczema affecting other parts of the body
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: endothermal ablation – where energy from either high-frequency radio waves or lasers is used to seal the affected veins
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: You should also speak to your GP if you have been using a topical corticosteroid and your symptoms have not improved.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: keep physically active – this will improve your circulation and help you maintain a healthy weight
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: sclerotherapy – where a special foam is injected into your veins to seal them
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: Varicose eczema is a long-term skin condition that affects the lower legs and is common in people with varicose veins.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: Read more about the causes of varicose eczema.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: Some people also have other symptoms, such as:
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: small, white scars (atrophie blanche)
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: See your GP if you have symptoms of varicose eczema. They will often be able to make a diagnosis simply by looking at the skin.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: There are a number of treatments available that can improve the symptoms and appearance of varicose veins, including:
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: red and swollen
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: There may be periods when these symptoms improve and periods when they become more severe.
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: dry and flaky
name: Varicose eczema

symptom: You should tell the person assessing you about the symptoms you experienced and how long they lasted. This will help to rule out other conditions.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: During a TIA, it’s not possible to tell whether you’re having a TIA or a full stroke, so it’s important to phone 999 immediately. Even if the symptoms disappear, you should still have an urgent assessment by a health professional.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: Like a stroke, the signs and symptoms of a TIA usually begin suddenly.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: TIAs are often over very quickly, so you may not have any symptoms by the time you see a health professional.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: anticoagulants like apixaban, edoxaban, rivaroxaban, dabigatran or warfarin
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: dizziness
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: Even if you no longer have symptoms, you might still need a neurological examination. This involves simple tasks designed to check your strength, sensation and co-ordination skills.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: difficulty understanding what others are saying
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: You might have some tests to rule out other causes of your symptoms and to help identify the underlying cause of your TIA.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: However, there may be other causes for these symptoms.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: Other signs and symptoms may include:
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: A person having a TIA or a stroke might not have all of these symptoms. If you notice any of these symptoms, you should consider a person may be having a stroke.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: Symptoms in the FAST test identify most strokes and TIAs. TIAs sometimes cause different symptoms that appear suddenly, usually over a few seconds.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: confusion
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: The main symptoms of stroke can be remembered with the word FAST.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: Although the symptoms of a TIA stop on their own, you’ll need treatment to help reduce the risk of another TIA or a full stroke.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: antiplatelets like aspirin and clopidogrel
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: complete paralysis of one side of the body
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: It’s important to be aware of the symptoms of a stroke or TIA, especially if you live with or care for somebody in a high-risk group, like an elderly person or someone with diabetes or high blood pressure.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: medication to lower your blood pressure (antihypertensives)
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: sudden loss or blurring of vision
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: The disruption in blood supply results in a lack of oxygen to the brain. This can cause sudden symptoms like those of a stroke.
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: statins to lower your cholesterol
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)

symptom: problems with balance and co-ordination
name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)
